text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: don’t drink water, don’t drink tea, don’t drink coffee, don’t drink juice, don’t drink milk, don’t drink anything. After dinner, just done. One, that will allow you to sleep because I think your prostate is acting up, it’s too big which means it’s blocking the way of the pee and then what happens is you pee but there’s stuff left over but your body doesn’t know it until just a little bit more accumulates in there and also your bladder is like oh, I was this full and now I’m this full, okay, I got to pee again and when you’re laying down you pee a lot easier because then your whole body is trying to recalibrate and what’s happening. So, at that point you got to pee some more. So, if you give it less reason to pee which means you don’t have enough fluid on board then you won’t pee because there’s not fluid to put through. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, you do me a favor and do that. I’ll work on getting your CAT scan and your bone scan set up and then we’ll figure out the next step. My thinking is that it probably - I’m going to shoot for the ah vaccine because once that’s done we don’t go back to it and then we just sort of put that and say done and then we move on to the other stuff. What do you think of that? Because if that sounds okay what takes forever is insurance Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: so if you’re kind of conceptually okay with that then I’m going to have J____, you know J____ who is our nurse, if you don’t know J____, you’re gonna know J____ in a minute. Patient: Is that the one that took the… Doctor: You had K____ Patient: K__ left. Doctor: but K____ left me so J____ is now working with me but actually J____ and I have worked together in the fifteen years I’ve been here. So, she was my original nurse that did a whole bunch of stuff but she’s always stayed on this team so she is also a very you know excellent prostate expert so she is going to help with trying to figure out if your insurance will say yes because it’s all great that you and I agree but if your insurance says, what are you kidding me, then we have to take that option off the table and just move on. Sound okay? Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: It’s kind of a lot today isn’t it? Patient: I want the best of what the best is for.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: It causes the DNA molecules in the cell, the genetic material of the cancer cell, to break into smaller pieces. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So the DNA molecule basically shatters into these small pieces and that damage is so catastrophic that the cell is unable to fix those DNA breaks and because the DNA molecule has been broken up into small little pieces, that cell can’t replicate itself and it dies. Patient: Oh! Doctor: So that’s the theoretical mechanism. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: We have shown that to be true in the laboratory both in cancer cells which are being grown in a plastic dish in the lab. Patient: Right. Doctor: In mostly mice that have prostate cancer. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: In humans we have some preliminary data that this is true. We have not conclusively proven that. And there are clearly patients who do not respond to this therapy. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: Sure. Doctor: And during that time you’re more tired is when your blood counts are low when you’re fighting infection. So we ask you not to travel on a plane those four days, if at all possible. If you do you have to wear a mask, and we ask you not to be around babies for those four days if possible because they’re infectious, not that you’re an injury to them. Patient: Right. Doctor: But other than that uh there really are no side effects. You may lose your hair temporarily. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, um, but it grows back. Um and you generally will only lose it for the last two doses. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So for about a month and a half you may have a hair problem. But that’s it. Patient: No long-term neuropathy or anything that? Doctor: Not, okay, so not with the four doses and uh not the way we give it because we really have tons you know of experience and we know how to give it, quite frankly. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If you went to the community, they give you six doses really high, and you would end up with neuropathy that’s pretty severe. Patient: Okay, um. Is there any detriment to having the chemo before the radiation?

text: Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: when you’re on a trial we can sometimes blame the new drug for that symptom and then that drug gets a black eye. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: I need to know what’s going on with your lungs because some of the treatments that we would talk about have toxicity to the lungs as one of the main side effects. Patient: Okay.

text: Family Member 1: I see. Doctor: So it’s, But it’s irrelevant. The cancer’s out. It’s an aggressive cancer. Family Member 1: Um Hmm. Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
